pros: Good working atmosphere, lovely coworkers
cons: Locate in downtown area, parking can be an issue

review_title: Changes in Higher Education make for challenging times
pros: Great colleagues, faculty, and wonderful student.
cons: Higher Education is in flux.

pros: Wonderful experience, great people who care about place
cons: Low pay because the college is low on funding

review_title: It was a good stepping stone to other opportunities
pros:
-At times, it was nice working at a small school. You have more direct access/facetime with upper management, and I wasn't totally overwhelmed by my student case load most of the time. 
-I learned a lot being able to interface with lots of different people/offices so it was a good stepping stone to a better position at another school. 
-Some of the people (staff and faculty) I worked with were really great and that made it better, although there were some terrible people and there was drama at times probably due to small work environment. I had multiple managers throughout my time there because we were shifting a lot of things- Most of them were good.
-There's also general perks of higher ed (time off/holidays, healthcare benefits, etc.)
cons:
- There was constant concern about money. Compensation seems to be low compared to other schools. When I started, they had a 401k match that they quickly reduced away because they needed to allocate that $ elsewhere. There were always rumors floating around the staff that we were going under, and still are to this day. 
- I took on a lot of extra work over the few years I was there and it took a lot of advocating for myself to have a title change/promotion/pay raise. It took almost a year for that to come, and at that point, I had found a job elsewhere. (This is typical of higher ed I suppose.)
- Upper management would act like they heard me / cared but would rarely take action.
- It was a toxic work environment at times with particular staff, some of which still work there.

pros: Opportunity to learn and grow for a reputable local school
cons: All roles onsite with limited flexibility (at the time)

pros: Housing was included, but not worth it.
cons: Unsupportive Staff Terrible Work Culture Administration is an absolute disaster.

job_title: Customer Service Representative (CSR) in Boston, MA
pros: Getting better overtime, slow but hopeful
cons: Things can be disorganized, management is slow to react

pros: Part of my compensation was room and board
cons:
Toxic, toxic, toxic work environment! 
I was employed while a graduate student in the residence life department. I was an older graduate student, having been full time employed for about 9 years prior in various environments before returning to school.
After my first semester the entire full time staff of the department turned over. Some of those staff got out because they were better than Simmons could ever provide for them. But one staff member was a bully who harassed many, if not all, of the part time employees - who were all students. The interim director knew about it but didn't do anything. Because they knew they were quitting. Eventually that bully staff member harassed a part time employee so seriously that I think they were asked to leave before legal got involved.
Following this entire staff turnover the department was incredibly short staffed with a new director taking over about a month prior to move in. This director is one of the most toxic people I have ever worked for and created an incredibly hostile work environment. It got to the point where the director literally stopped speaking to part time employees. Just walk right past us. The part time employees tried expressing their concerns to the director directly a couple times to just be completed gaslighted. At one point the director threw a piece of paper across a table at us. Then we brought our concerns to the VP of the university who told us that if we didn't want to work there to just quit. Keep in mind They said this to student employees. They said this after 20+ student employees all voiced the same concerns. I understand sticking up for the new person in the department but the music needed to be faced and instead students were told to get over themselves. 
Then the department became fully staffed in December. By June, every single December hire had quit. A whole new staff turnover.
This job negativity affected my opinion of the school as a whole institution. I would never ever recommend anyone work there and I've even recommended against attending there because of my experience there. The way I heard full time employees, who all had at least masters degrees in higher education, speak about students was appalling. And they would just laugh about it. It was awful. I stuck it out because I had no where else to live and still be able to attend classes. And that's a sentiment that many of the part time employees expressed - that they couldn't speak up, they had to deal with the abuse, otherwise they'd be homeless. What an awful situation to put students in.

review_title: Don't work at Simmons, not worth the stress and burnout.
pros: Wonderful, dedicated, hardworking people and coworkers and colleagues for the most part. Supporting students and faculty can be a rewarding experience.
cons:
PERPETUAL BURNOUT, NO RESOURCES, NO SUPPORT FROM UPPER ADMINISTRATION, LOW PAY, NO RAISES, SUBPAR BENEFITS .
As wonderful as the colleagues can be, it is not worth the stress, lack of work life balance, and constant state of emergency. Demands are increasing, but resources and staff are staying the same or even decreasing due to pandemic layoffs. So many administrative support staff have left since Summer 2021 and are continuing to leave. Students are suffering. Staff are miserable.

job_title: Senior Administrative Assistant in Boston, MA
pros: Depending on your department, you are either double-staffed or have too many free hours throughout the day.  The  students are incredible and eager to learn- very professional. The university has good benefits- decent time off/sick time, 401k, etc. Coworkers are friendly/helpful.  Great mission statement & women-focused curriculum.
cons: There is always a sinking feeling that the floor will drop from under you. The school does a poor job of motivating the staff to not only feel secure, but to excel in their role. There is little to no job advancement- there is increase job responsibility with no title change (takes 6+ months...) or pay increase. The management sends out lengthy emails to update the school on anything they deem important. There are community meanings annually, but the environment is never innovative or productive. People ask questions and are given not-so-nice replies.  Huge decisions are either made without thinking them through enough or they take 5 years.  Lots of administrative hoops to jump through to get ahead, but that's moreso a higher-ed problem.  For a women-focused institution, they do little to advance their employees. No professional development.

pros: The staff & faculty are dedicated to the educational mission and success of students.  The Simmons community strives to create an environment that is at the forefront of inclusivity on gender, race, etc.  The College is conveniently located to public transportation, shopping and Fenway Park!  The benefits are okay.
cons: In the time I've been here, the benefits are diminishing, although to be fair that is nationwide with the changes in healthcare.  This is a high-stress environment, with staffing reductions, and increasing responsibility for the positions that remain.  There is a general distrust of administration, and low employee morale. Salary increases are infrequent, and well below the pace of inflation. Each year at Simmons has decreased my purchasing power.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in San Juan, PR
pros:
People you work with. Training for new employees is getting better.
It's a good place to round out your skills, as you learn A/V technologies and more 'standard' tech support technologies and procedures.
Immediate supervisors are great and work with you.
cons:
Some 'customers' (faculty/staff) have a holier than though attitude. Student money goes to computers and equipment that a lot of these employees treat like garbage with no thought to the consequences. But all of them want the latest and greatest. They are aloof to the situation in higher education and maybe a good amount of the issue comes from lack of communication from College Leadership. 

For a College with so many modern liberal values, some of people are stuck way in the past.

review_title: Good job for people that need flexible PT, terrible every other way.

pros:
- Work your own schedule on the days/times you can.

This is just about it.
cons:

review_title: Great people, great students, struggling leadership.
pros: Faculty, staff and students are very smart and are doing amazing things and it's great to support this.  It is a great place to work for very specific types of jobs. I advise anyone job hunting here to understand who they will work with and what resources and support they might get.
cons: Not large enough for personal growth; like many small colleges, there is little money to go around and lots of competition. The structure was very entrenched and it is difficult for anyone to move there.

review_title: The tricky thing about compromise - don't do it if it hurts inside....
pros:
- standard hours
- easy commute
- good benefits package
- vacation/sick time + paid administrative holidays
- get your degree paid for
cons:
- "accepting" community depends on where in the community you work or learn
- limited to no employee support: human resources no longer supports employees
- over-worked employees under new management strategies to decrease fiscal overhead
- virtually no communication, bad blood between departments
- derisive gap between faculty and staff

pros:
-Free graduate degrees for employees and spouses
-Great rates on public transit
-Easy location to commute to
-Some very talented staff sprinkled throughout college- always a pleasure when you find them!
cons:
-Leadership is lacking (President is demeaning, HR is nonexistent, no clear vision/unity/community)
-No merit pay increase in 5 years running
-Generally very difficult to obtain a raise, even with stellar reviews (usually HR blocking)
-No way for staff to communicate needs (falls on deaf ears)
-Lack of unity between staff & faculty
-Lots of politics (have to beware of what you say and who you are saying it to)

review_title: A good campus job for STEM students
pros: Great way to stay sharp on course material while helping other students.  Flexible schedule.  Demand varies a lot by tutoring topic, so a stats, chem, or bio tutor might get more appointments than say a French tutor.  Appointments can be a little sporadic, but it's a good gig if you can get a few regulars (i.e. a tutee who comes once every week).
cons: Appointments could be scheduled as little as 12 hours before meeting time, so you had to check the schedule regularly (or your email if you sign up for alerts).

pros: The pros of working at Simmons include the opportunity to grow and develop professionally.  There is always a program or workshop to help one improve skill sets.  The communication is open.
cons: Simmons is going through some changes.  It is not the same professional nuturer it used to be.  For a while morale was down.

pros: Working as a fellow at Simmons was a great experience because of a supportive learning environment where I was free to learn new skills by being thrown into new situations. Professors and staff were always treating me like a colleague and not a student. Learned a wide variety of skills and confidence from my time there.
cons: Not able to get a lot of hours, and no room for moving up. Not many opportunities at all in each department of school. You need to know someone to get hired it seems.

review_title: Simmons is very small, but everyone is extremely nice and pleasant. It was great working here.
pros: It has a nice small and intimate vibe. You'll quickly meet everyone and occasionally see them on campus. I worked with an academic department office and all of the faculty was great. I learned a lot of the basics of office administration, but it wasn't that exciting.
cons: Sometimes Simmons being a small campus has it drawbacks because you feel like there isn't a lot of room for growth.

pros:

review_title: Poor salaries, low morale, and bad management

cons: Very low salaries across the board, poor management that is not transparent and that listens very little to its employees. This overall creates extremely low morale.

review_title: Seek Their Employment At Your Own Risk
pros: The college is all girls, enough said about that. You might learn a great deal depending on your department and you might work with some good people. I worked with their Technology department and was able to learn a good amount of computing, event, and troubleshooting skills. I was also able to work with some really good and interesting people.
cons: You may have heard of Simmons being a great multicultural and diverse school, well that's a fat lie. It's predominately white and is suffering from a lack of Multicultural Diversity. If you're looking for employment with Simmons Technology, TURN AND RUN AWAY! First off, they will interview you and make it seem like the place is really high class and make you feel like your applying to a very serious job..WRONG. No matter what position the technology department hires you for from your set of skills, they wont tell you that you will be required to do EVERY job which includes, phones, tech support, event support, printer support, classroom support and so on regardless if you have experience in doing it or not. If you have a question on how to do things they will most likely refer you to "techknow" which is their data base for how to's and changes to procedures which is rarely updated and is full of out of date processes or they will just throw you into the fire and basically make you figure it out. I was hired as an events person and learned harshly that events was not all I would do. The job is extremely thankless and they will work you like a slave! The other faculty and staff are terribly fussy, short tempered, pampered, and expect the world from you at the drop of a dime and feel entitled to whatever they want. The scheduling is horrible and you basically have to fight for hours that are all set up in 2,3, and 4 hour increments and what ever is left over gets randomly thrown into your work schedule. They will also schedule you on certain days regardless of your availability and if your time is limited or you work other jobs, be prepared to work 1 to two days a week there. There is next to no communication from full time employees (management) to the part timers and if something goes wrong, they all point fingers instead of solving the problem. They have secret employee reviews and I'm not joking, they have meetings and some of them are to review the employees BUT, they don't give YOU the employee any of that feed back. They also don't give raises so whatever rate you're hired with you're stuck with that. There is virtually no room for advancement unless someone dies or leaves because they too tire of the B/s. Unless you're a starving college kid, a co-op, or being hired for full time, there is no reason to work at Simmons Technology as a Part Time employee. Part Timer = slave, they don't care much about their employees. Full time people will get paid rather well but you need to decide if the pay is worth the endless amount of crap you will have to put up with.
